#proposedmeetingtopic Drop support for Ubuntu 22.04 LTS as a build platform
Why?

So sipa and i had a look into the high memory usage of v29 vs v28 reported in the SE post i linked yesterday. Our best guess (well really sipa's and it makes sense to me too) is that this is due to #30039. With this change the bitcoind process will mmap larger LevelDB files, causing a higher reported memory usage. In case of memory pressure the
kernel will just drop those so it won't lead to an OOM.

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/30039 | dbwrapper: Bump LevelDB max file size to 32 MiB to avoid system slowdown from high disk cache flush rate by maciejsszmigiero · Pull Request #30039 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
darosior please put n issue if you haven't (goes without saying)
But it's still mildly annoying that common utilities like `top` will report it as memory actively used by bitcoind, which may confuse (more) users.
instagibbs: wouldn't have gone without you asking
fanquake: mostly due to outdated and problematic to maintain packages in default repositories: cmake, qt, capnp
qt & capnp from depends should be fine?
sure
if there's something that's broken with cmake, worth knowing
in April 2026, when Core v31 will be released, another LTS will be available
no, cmake is _not_ broken; but we are not able to use newer useful features
darosior there are dozens of us top users
still, 22.04 is supported until 2027
correct
instagibbs: i'm on it
i'd hate to be in a situation where some important user chooses not to upgrade because they want to build from source, and they're stuck on an older platform
so i guess it's a trade-off, how important are those features
not as much as some important user
sipa: apparently it's already the case that some users are stuck, i.e https://x.com/_Dr_Bond_/status/1964827406252081565
unless something is broken, I don't see why we'd "drop support" for something, if everything still works fine
fanquake: i mean, it's a similar consideration we make for e.g. updating to a new C++ standard, which implies dropping support for some older platforms
You mean in the case that the default compiler can no-longer compile the source?
right
I do sometimes wish we could get users to install a newer compiler, if there system one is aging
In this case, I'm not sure we should drop support for an LTS distro, because of an old, not actually broken, CMake
I was expecting this outcome :)
It'd be good if you could elaborate on what the actual problem is
It's not clear what the "newer/useful" CMake features, we need to start using
my initial motivation mostly was not about CMake features, but rather my personal burden to keep Ubuntu 22.04 LTS instance and perform testing on it
among useful CMake features are: file sets (https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/target_sources.html#file-sets), `COMPILE_WARNING_AS_ERROR, better support for IPO/LTO, scope management etc
Opened #33351 to document higher memory usage post 29.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33351 | Higher **reported** memory usage of Bitcoin Core after version 29 · Issue #33351 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub

You are all a disgusting heap of shit and should be embarassed by yourselves and your actions.   I hope that Saylor goes broke, Lightning gets hacked, the exchanges choke on a pile of a shit, and you die a miserable death.
charming
